it's miniature.

how old is the dog?

it's still just a pup.

she weighs in at about fifty pounds, so she's a medium size.
But she's big enough to be intimidating,
she was teaching me.
Oh, I wouldn't doubt it, yeah.
She's the most intelligent dog I've ever seen.

But, next morning, she let me know in no uncertain terms that she wanted to use the bathroom.
So, on next night, I spread the newspaper in the bathroom and she used them there.
But it wasn't too long until she, found out she could wait until I let her out in the morning.
I live alone.
we've always got, got a nose and tongue pressed up against the window when we come walking up to the front door.
She's definitely ready to get out and run around.

she does not like to be indoors.
she'd rather sleep outside on the cold ground at night.

And I feed her indoors
that's to lure her in, but during the day I have her on a on a leash,
which is, on sort of a run. I have a, a thirty foot cable,
running from one stake to another, and then attached to that is a twelve foot leash,
so she can cover quite an area.

she acts like she wants to chew their leg off.
the line is between children and adults.

she is a great comfort to me.

if the child is pretty straight forward she's fine.

we took her home to my family's place in South Dakota
she was the one that was intimidated then.

what do you call the dog?

he was a real lovable type,

I was wondering whether you were in favor of statehood, independence, or the status quo for Puerto Rico.
I guess I have a left over positive feeling about the question even though I don't know very much about Puerto Rico.
I know that all the things that happened relative to that territory in Alaska have been very positive.
I have a suspicion that the statehood is a good idea whenever you have a territory the size of Puerto Rico.
What is your situation?
I guess I don't have such close experience with an area becoming a state as you do.
My concern is the economy because as I understand it Puerto Rico has a very low standard of living.
Part of this I suppose is justified in that the climate they don't need.
I guess I would favor status quo.
I have been to Puerto Rico and, and found it very, very interesting.
I did Peace Corps training there.
Oh that's very interesting.
you know I saw it
it was very foreign in a certain sense
I had grown up in California and so the Spanish was no problem.
It was very lovely and the people seemed very friendly and nice.
I work with a girl from Puerto Rico
I guess I have never thought to ask her what she favors.
I'm not quite sure how the they cope with this sort of thing.
I've live abroad most of my life
I've been very cut off.
I lived actually in Lebanon
I was very cut off from the press as I was becoming an adult.
I don't know how the they would cope with a new state that is so very poor.
I suppose the whole country would require such aid.
Perhaps compulsory education.
taxes would undoubtedly be occurring.
I don't even understand exactly how taxes are handled in a territorial situation.
the laws in a territory are in some ways as stringent as they are in other states.
I had thought of it more in terms of political realization.
Well it sounds as though you are in favor of the status quo.
I believe I would probably tend towards that.
I think if I were being forced to make a decision I would plead ignorance.
I guess I'm ultimately in favor of status quo also at this point.
What about if they demanded to have Spanish as the official language as a condition for statehood.
I don't think there is any prohibitions.
I would be bothered by that.
I'm bothered by any tendency to resist what I think was one of my strengths.
I am particularly fond of a number of ethnic cuisines
I'm troubled by too close a clinging to the past
a common language is the ultimate bond of a country.
I was in bilingual education in California.
I didn't have any problem with my students.
I noticed my brother was learning Spanish in elementary school.
And so, obviously it didn't work in California.
Yeah, but I'm rather in favor of people being bilingual.
I'd be quite happy to see a national law in which every student was required to learn English and a second language.
I'm disturbed by a country that attempts to be functionally bilingual at the official level.
I'm concerned about whether or not that causes fractiousness.
I think we have gone to time
I appreciate your having called.
Okay, well thank you very much.
Good bye.
Bye, bye.
